In this demonstration, you will see how the payment plan controls the way BillingCenter slices a premium charge into installments and places them on invoices. Here's Kerb Smith's account. I'm going to open the policy issuance wizard to quickly add a policy with a premium charge. I select Add Policy from the Actions menu. This time I'll create a Homeowners policy. Let's give it a policy number. I select Homeowners as the product. I'll use the same payment plan that we used in the previous demo. Here's PP07. I select it. Let's move on to step 2. I click Add to create the premium charge. The amount of the charge is $1,804. I type in the amount. And click Finish. We're back at the account summary. Let's take a look at the charge first. I click Charges in the sidebar. The premium charge is listed at the top of the screen. Below the charge, it's easy to see the 25% down payment in the 11 installments that resulted from the charge. How did the down payment and first installment end up on the same invoice? The answer is, Look at the invoice bill date of the first invoice. Now look at the placement dates of the down payment item and the first installment item. Both invoice items have placement dates that are on or before the invoice bill date. Let's look at the invoices. The first invoice has both the down payment and first installment. Looking at the second invoice, we see just one installment. This explains the difference in placement dates between the down payment and first installment items. Is there a way to ensure that the down payment and first installment land on different invoices? In this demonstration, I'll show how BillingCenter charges an invoice fee according to the Accounts Billing Plan. Here is the Account Summary screen for the Lauren Ramirez account. To find the Accounts Billing Plan, we'll go to the Account Details. I'll click BP02 to go to the plan. Notice the plan specifies a $2 invoice fee. Let's return to the Account Details screen. Next, I'll go to the Invoices tab. I can see the first invoice is for $410. The bill date is today, so no need to advance the clock. Let's switch to Super User to run the invoice batch process. Here's the invoice batch process. I click Run. Now let's return to Jeff Park. To refresh the screen, I click on the Next Invoice. Notice the first invoice is now billed. Let's look at the invoice items for the first invoice. Here's the one-time fee in the amount of $2. The invoice fee charge was added by the invoice batch process. Let's look at the first planned invoice. This invoice only has a premium item of $123 and no invoice fee item. Why is there no invoice fee on the planned invoice? The answer is, invoice fees are created by the invoice batch process only when it changes the invoice status from plan to build. Now let's look at the payment requests screen. I click the menu icon for payments in the sidebar. Now I click Payment Requests. As we know, this account has a non-responsive payment instrument. Here's the payment request. The invoice batch process created the payment request on the invoice bill date. Notice the status is created and the request date is tomorrow. Let's return to Super User to advance the clock by a day and run a batch process. We first go to Internal Tools. Here's the testing system clock menu item. I click Add Day. The clock has been advanced by a day. Now we'll go to Server Tools. Here's the payment request batch process, which I'll run now. Let's return to Jeff Park to see what's happened to our payment request. First, I refresh the screen by clicking to another screen. And now I return to Payment Requests. Notice the status of the payment request has changed to Requested. As time advances and the other payment request dates are reached, the payment request batch process will update the payment request statuses accordingly. This concludes our demonstration on invoice fees and payment requests.

Ashley Peterson, a policyholder, has requested a change to her due date. The billing clerk agrees to modify the due date to the 15th of every month. In this demonstration, we see how to make the requested change. Let's take a look at Ashley's invoices. Notice the first invoice is billed. The other invoices are planned. The payment allocation plan is used by BillingCenter to automatically apply payments. In this demonstration, we take a look at the various settings on a payment allocation plan. Payment allocation plans are on the Administration tab along with the other BillingCenter plans. I click the arrow to expand Business Settings. And I click Payment Allocation Plans. The default payment allocation plan is shipped with BillingCenter. Let's take a look at it. The default payment allocation plan can be modified or used without changes. Another option is to clone it to use it as a starting point for a custom plan. This is what I will do. First I click Clone. The middle section of the plan is called what invoice items should be paid. When the payment allocation process runs, it looks at all unsettled invoice items associated with the account. The term settled means fully paid. Unsettled is not fully paid. This is where you can specify the invoice items to include in the payment allocation. Let's take a look at a few of the filters that are selected. I'll click the sort arrow icon in the name column to put these in alphabetical order. First, we have the Build or Do filter selected. This means that payment allocation will only consider invoice items that have a status of either Build or Do. Planned invoice items will not be included. As you saw in the previous demo, a payment can be earmarked for a specific invoice or policy period. The invoice and policy period filters ensure that a payment that is targeted for a specific invoice or policy period is applied only to that target. Finally, we have the positive filter. This filter restricts payment allocation to invoice items that have amounts greater than zero. There are additional filters in Billing Center that are not currently used in this plan. I'll click add to see what else is available. Next planned invoice, if selected, includes invoice items from the next planned invoice. Pass due restricts invoice items to those that are past due. Let's go back to our clone plan. Billing Center warns me that unsaved changes will be discarded. That's okay. Now that we've discussed filters, let's turn our attention to the bottom section of the screen. This is where the invoice item payment priority is specified. The priority determines the order in which invoice items will be paid. The priority list directs billing center to pay recapture charges first. Next billing center pays invoice items in order of their placement dates, oldest first, and finally, if there is money left over, the payment priority is by charge pattern priority. By the way, a recapture charge represents money the insurer wants to get back from a policyholder after an incorrect disbursement. As with filters, there are additional items you can use to prioritize the order in which a payment is applied to invoice items. I'll click add to take a look at these. There are a number of payment priority items available. Let's focus on Spread Access Even. This priority item tells the payment allocation plan to pay all billed and due invoice items first. And then if there is money left over, to pay the planned items proportionally. So let's select Spread Access Even. I click add priority. Our new priority item is now listed as the fourth priority item. I can control the order of the payment priorities, using the arrows in the move priority column. I'll click the move up arrow next to placement date to move it to the top. This means that items will first be paid in order of their placement dates. Now I'm going to move placement date back down by clicking on the move down arrow, because I want to pay recapture charges first. We've finished examining a payment allocation plan, so I'll just click cancel. This concludes our demonstration on payment allocation plans. We'll see you next time!

Notice the status of the suspense payment has been changed to Applied. I'll revisit the Account Summary for Standox. I select the Standox account from the drop-down list. In the Account Summary for Standox, we can see there is $1,800 in the total unapplied field. I'll click this link. The Unapplied Funds detail screen shows that the $1,800 payment is in the unapplied fund for this policy. Both the manual and automatic approaches to releasing suspense payments achieve the intended results. This concludes our demonstration on handling suspense payments. In this demonstration, we are going to look at a scenario where a payment was received, but was applied to the wrong policy. Our customer, Todd Davidson, has a homeowner's policy and a personal auto policy with us. He paid for both policies using a single check. We have learned that the payment was not applied as he requested. Instead, the whole payment was applied to the homeowner's policy. The account summary shows the two policies, homeowner's and personal auto. Also, I see that the graph shows that $840 has been paid, but there is still an amount of $300 that has been billed but not paid. So let's fix this problem. We'll start by looking at the payment. I click payments in the sidebar. Here we can see the payment of $840. I'll click the payments so that we can view the payment details. The first two rows show the payment was applied to the billed invoice. The third row shows that $300 of the payment was applied to the next planned invoice. Instead, the $300 should have been applied to the billed invoice for the personal auto policy. Let's modify the payment. I'll select Modify Distribution from the list of payment actions. The Modify Payment screen is similar to the Direct Bill Payment screen. The Distribution tab shows that the payment has been applied to the billed and planned invoices for the homeowner's policy. I can reallocate the payment by adding invoice items from the personal auto policy to the allocation. First I click Override Distribution. Notice the Override toolbar is now displayed. I click Add Items to find all billed items, which I want to add to the payment distribution. The Add Items screen allows me to search for and then add unsettled invoice items from any policy to the payment allocation. Note the payer account is already set as a search criterion. I click Search. My first search returns several items. I decide to restrict the next search to invoice items that are on invoices with a billed status. I click the Build Status field. I select Billed from the list of statuses. Now I click Search. This time the search returned just two billed items. I click the checkbox next to each item. Now I click Add Selected Items. Notice the plus icon next to the items I added. The icon lets me know that these are the manually added items. The red amount in the remaining fields shows more money will be allocated than is available. To get a clearer view of the billed and planned invoices, I click the Aggregate field. I want to see a summary of the invoices. To remove the proposed allocation for the planned invoice, I click in the Override Amount field for the planned invoice. I enter 0 as the override amount. Now the available and distributed amounts are equal. To apply the modified payment allocation, I'll click Execute. On the Payments screen, we can see that the entire payment has been applied to billed invoice items only. Let's return to the Account Summary screen. In the Financials section of the screen, the pie chart details show that $840 has been paid and the billed amount is $0. I successfully modified the payment allocation as requested by the customer. This concludes our demonstration on reallocating a payment. For this demonstration, I'm going to show you how to test delinquency processing. In a production system, delinquency processing occurs over a period of weeks. However, by manually advancing the testing clock and running batch processes, we can see the whole delinquency process in a few minutes. I have set up a test policy for the Ella Lundstrom account. We're looking at the invoices screen for the account. The first invoice is due and has been paid in full. The second invoice is billed but not paid. Notice the date in the info bar is the due date of the second invoice. This invoice has not been paid yet. Let's go to the account summary. Here we see an alert bar to indicate this account will become delinquent if the expected payment is not received today. Now I'll open the policy. Here we see a similar alert about the upcoming delinquency on the policy summary. Let's switch to superuser to make the policy delinquent. First, I'll advance the clock by one day. Then I go to the server tools tab. I scroll the display to find the invoice due batch process. Here is invoice due. I click run. Let's return to Jeff Park to see the result. To refresh the browser, I click the details link in the sidebar. Then I click the summary link to return to the policy summary screen. Let's take a look at what has changed on the policy summary screen. The screen has been designed to quickly provide the most commonly needed information about an active delinquency. The alert bar message has changed to an alert stating the policy has a past due delinquency. The delinquencies field has been updated to show this policy has had one delinquency in 12 months. In the financials section, the past due field displays the past due amount and also indicates a $50 late fee has been charged. The policy summary screen gives us the high level status of this account. Now, let's view the details of the delinquency process. I'll do this by clicking on the link in the alert bar to open the delinquencies screen. This screen shows the delinquency is open and the delinquency reason is past due. I'll scroll to show the events area of the screen. Here we see a list of the workflow events that you can use to track delinquency processing. Two events have completed, Dunning Letter 1 and Late Fee. The next event is Dunning Letter 2, which will cause a second Dunning Letter to be sent to the delinquent policyholder. Inception date refers to the start date of the delinquency. In the example, the inception date is one day after the due date of the unpaid invoice, which is today. The Dunning Letter 2 event is scheduled for inception date plus seven days. So I'll switch to Super User and add seven days to the billing center date. First I'll go to internal tools to advance the testing system clock. I select testing system clock from the menu. Now I click add week to advance the clock to the date of the Dunning Letter 2 event. Next, I need to run a batch process to wake up the workflow. I click the server tools tab. I scroll the list to locate the workflow writer batch process. Now I click run. Let's return to the Jeff Park browser to see the result. To refresh the display, I click the journal link in the sidebar. Now I return to the delinquencies screen. Immediately, I see the current event is Dunning Letter 2 and the next event is send notice of intent to cancel. Let's look at the second activity. The workflow has updated the Dunning Letter 2 event to show the event is complete and the date it was completed. The workflow has also created two activities. The general activity is an activity that specifies the Dunning Letter was sent. I'll click the details link so that we get more information about this activity. We can see the subject, description and priority. This activity is really just an informational activity and does not require any user action. Let's look at the second activity. The second activity is different from the general activity. It is an approval activity that requires approval to be approved. The second activity is a result of the cancellation. Notice the mandatory column is set to yes. This activity is mandatory because the delinquency workflow is waiting for this activity to be completed. I'll click the details link so that we get more information about this activity. Notice this activity has an approve button. It also has a due date and an escalation date. If this activity is not completed by the escalation date, it will be escalated based on business rules. Although the activity is not assigned to me, I can approve it, so I click approve.
